conclusion: An ideal gas undergoes the ABCDA cycle on a P-V diagram, forming a rectangle with pressures P1, P2 and volumes V1, V2. Temperature at state A is T0.
From A to B: Pressure increases from P1 to P2 at constant volume V1.
From B to C: Volume increases from V1 to V2 at constant pressure P2.
From C to D: Pressure decreases from P2 to P1 at constant volume V2.
From D to A: Volume decreases from V2 to V1 at constant pressure P1.
The process is a rectangular cycle on the P-V diagram, with each process being either constant pressure or constant volume.
Use the ideal gas equation PV = nRT, where n is constant throughout the cycle.

premise: From A to B: Volume is constant (V1), pressure increases from P1 to P2.
From B to C: Pressure is constant (P2), volume increases from V1 to V2.
Using the ideal gas law: PA * VA = n * R * TA and PC * VC = n * R * TC
